None of the available solutions is completely satisfying. I often feel 
the necessity of testing private methods, and have tried the solutions 
offered here.
For quite a while I used the static inner classes technique, but found 
that with time our source files were getting too cluttered.
I've now moved to putting my test cases in a parallel directory with the 
same package structure, and if I really need to test a private method I 
change the access to package-private and can then test it directly from 
a test class in the same package, but in a different source tree. With a 
few good Ant targets and/or scripts this works nicely. Still, changing a 
private method representing an implementation detail to package-private 
seems to be a code smell!

Eric Armstrong wrote:
> "Mike Colbert " wrote:
> 
> 
>> One technique we use, with Java, is to implement our JUnit TestCases
>>as static inner classes.  This gives you the access you require.  It
>>also provides other benefits, especially with TDD.  It makes managing
>>the source a lot easier.  You only have to check in/out one file from
>>SCM.  That way you never, ahem, forget the test code.  It's always
>>married to the app code.  This helps enforce a mindset that the test
>>code is just as important as the app code.  And it's really
>>comfortable to bounce up and down the single file in your editor as
>>you iterate between writing test code and app code.  Deployment is
>>not a problem, since inner classes are compiled into seperate class
>>files, using the AppClass$TestClass.class naming convention.
